text:
This world, which is the same for all, no one of gods or men has made. But it always was and will be: an ever-living fire, with measures of it kindling, and measures going out.
All things are an interchange for fire, and fire for all things, just like goods for gold and gold for goods.
Fire lives the death of earth, and air lives the death of fire; water lives the death of air, earth that of water.
God is day and night, winter and summer, war and peace, surfeit and hunger; but he takes various shapes, just as fire, when it is mingled with spices, is named according to the savor of each.
The sun is new each day.
The thunderbolt steers the universe.

The waking have one common world, but the sleeping turn aside each into a world of his own.
To those who are awake, there is one ordered universe common (to all), whereas in sleep each turns away to one of his own.
Fools when they do hear are like the deaf: of them does the saying bear witness that they are absent when present.
Eyes and ears are bad witnesses to men if they have souls that understand not the language.
The many do not take heed of such things as those they meet with, nor do they mark them when they are taught, but they think they do.
Dogs bark at everyone they do not know.
One man is ten thousand to me, if he be the best.

You cannot step twice into the same river.
Into the same rivers we step and do not step, we are and are not.
On those who step into the same rivers, different and different waters flow.
We must know that war is common to all and strife is justice, and that all things come into being and pass away through strife.
The way up and the way down is one and the same.
